name: epilobium
country-or-region-of-origin: All over the world except the hotest areas.
edibility: Fireweed is used as a sweetener in northwestern North America. It is put in candy, jellies, ice cream, syrup, and sxusem ("Indian ice cream"). Bees produce rich spicy honey from the nectar. Leaves and stems edible if cooked.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: The fruit is a slender cylindrical capsule containing numerous seeds embedded in fine, soft silky fluff which disperses the seeds in the wind.
flower-description: The flowers have four petals that may be notched to deeply notched. These are usually smallish and pink in most species, but red, orange or yellow in a few. May occur as a panicle.
leaf-description: Leaves are usually opposite and rarely whorled and sometimes sessile. They are simple and ovate to lanceolate in shape. The leaves may or may not have hairs.
stem-description: Stems may be smooth or hairy and are winged.
uses: Used as a herbal supplement in the treatment of prostate, bladder (incontinence) and hormone disorders. Sap from the stem used on wounds for anti-inflammatory properties.
